results.headline: Something Forgotten in an Eerie Denmark
results.summary_short: “Just Another Love Story” administers a stinging slap in the face to the popular notion of Denmark as one of the happiest places on earth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just Another Love Story

results.headline: Under the Microscope: A Marriage Sorely Tested
results.summary_short: “Not Easily Broken” presents a world in which women no longer regard men as heroes.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Not Easily Broken

results.headline: Two Weddings and a Furor
results.summary_short: Do Hollywood studio executives think that women have a gene for tulle? Neural receptors just for Vera Wang? I wondered this as I was watching “Bride Wars.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bride Wars

results.headline: Bad Soviet Memories Keep on Curdling
results.summary_short: Art house meets grind house in “Cargo 200,” Alexey Balabanov’s morbidly compelling thriller set in the Soviet Union.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cargo 200

results.headline: Aligning With the Nazis, Blindfold Tightly in Place
results.summary_short: “Good” is an anemic screen adaptation of C. P. Taylor’s play about a respectable “good German” who passively acquiesces to Hitler’s agenda.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good

results.headline: A Society in the Forest, Banding Together to Escape Persecution
results.summary_short: Edward Zwick’s stiff, musclebound new movie tells the true story of the Bielski partisans, who fought the Nazis and rescued hundreds of Jews through the darkest years of war and genocide.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Defiance

results.headline: Two Faces in the Crowd, Raging Against the Crab Grass
results.summary_short: “Revolutionary Road,” a waxworks edition of the furiously unsentimental novel by Richard Yates, tracks the unraveling of a handsome young suburban couple in the 1950s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revolutionary Road

results.headline: There She Is, Miss ... Well, Actually, It’s Mr.
results.summary_short: “Pageant” goes behind the scenes, dreams, breakdowns, freakouts, sequins, glitter and fabulous falsies of the Miss Gay America pageant.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pageant

results.headline: Inside a Veteran’s Nightmare
results.summary_short: The animated documentary “Waltz With Bashir” is a memoir, a history lesson, a combat picture, a piece of investigative journalism and an altogether amazing film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Waltz with Bashir

results.headline: It’s the Age of a Child Who Grows From a Man
results.summary_short: “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button” sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonist’s condition.
results.display_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Curious Case of Benjamin Button

results.headline: Mission Imperative: Assassinate the Führer
results.summary_short: “Valkyrie” transforms World War II into a boy’s adventure.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valkyrie

results.headline: Returned From the Dead, Ducking Villains and Vixens
results.summary_short: What is most striking about “The Spirit” is how little pleasure it affords, in spite of its efforts to be sly, sexy, heartfelt and clever all at once.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Spirit

results.headline: Going to the Dog and Getting a Life
results.summary_short: To watch “Marley & Me” is to tune in to an era that seems so close and yet so distant.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marley & Me

results.headline: The Clock You Hear? It’s Not Big Ben, Buddy
results.summary_short: There’s something irresistible about watching two people fall in love, even in contrived, sniffle- and sometimes gag-inducing films like “Last Chance Harvey.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Chance Harvey

results.headline: Once Upon a Time, There Was a Resentful Handyman Who Agreed to Baby-Sit
results.summary_short: In “Bedtime Stories” the pain of this artistic limbo is written all over Adam Sandler’s character, a resentful hotel handyman named Skeeter.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bedtime Stories

results.headline: Humble Souls, Richly Nourished
results.summary_short: The richness of “The Secret of the Grain” lies in the close, tireless, enthusiastic attention it pays to the most mundane daily tasks.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secret of the Grain

results.headline: Mother Courage Gets Her Own Camp Follower
results.summary_short: In his inspired, inspiring essayistic documentary “Theater of War,” the filmmaker John Walter jumps from art to history and politics and back again.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Theater of War

results.headline: The Pursuit of Happiness Is a Complicated Affair
results.summary_short: The steady attention to detail in “Moscow, Belgium” lends it a texture rarely found in films about domestic life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moscow, Belgium

results.headline: Nowhere Man, Listen Up: You Have to Stop Saying No
results.summary_short: “Yes Man” is too sluggish and slapdash a vehicle for its star’s prodigious wackiness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yes Man

results.headline: Killer Soup, and a Mouse to the Rescue
results.summary_short: “Despereaux” is a pleasantly immersive, beautifully animated, occasionally sleepy tale.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tale of Despereaux
